docs.text: Overview ⚓︎ dRAX RIC xApps Development Guide Doc Ref dRAX-xApps-01 Version 2.0.0 xApp Framework Version 2.0.0 dRAX Version Support 4.0.0, 4.1.0 Date 22.12.2021. About This Document This document is intended as a guide for developers creating xApps for the dRAX platform. Copyright Notice Accelleran copyrights this dRAX xApps Development Guide. No part of this document may be reproduced in any form or means, without the prior written consent of Accelleran. Disclaimer This specification is preliminary and is subject to change at any time without notice. Accelleran assumes no responsibility for any errors contained herein. For more information, please consult our customer support. Contact Us Accelleran NV, Quellinstraat 49, 2018, Antwerpen, Belgium, EU E-mail: customer.support@accelleran.com Phone: +32 489 602 684 Website: http://www.accelleran.com/ Version history ⚓︎ Author Note Date Version Ensar Zeljkovic First draft with table of contents 06.05.2020. 0.0.1 Ensar Zeljkovic Restructuring to new xApp Framework Package 24.09.2020. 0.0.2 Ensar Zeljkovic Pre-Release ready for review 07.10.2020. 0.1.0 Antoine Dugast Adding Extendable API overview 25.03.2021. 0.2.0 Antoine Dugast Adding README documentation 09.04.2021. 0.3.0 Ensar Zeljkovic Incorporating API and README documentation 13.04.2021. 0.3.1 Ensar Zeljkovic New Development workflow 14.04.2021 0.4.0 Ensar Zeljkovic Align with dRAX-4.0.0 03.12.2021 1.0.0 Gerwin Dox Sync with xApp Library rework. 28.07.2021 2.0.0-rc0 Gerwin Dox Sync with Lib version 0.3 29.11.2021 2.0.0-rc1 Ensar Zeljkovic Review and edits for xApp Library update 14.12.2021. 2.0.0-rc2 Ensar Zeljkovic Adding ChangeLog section 22.12.2021. 2.0.0 Changelog ⚓︎ Added ⚓︎ Added xApp Library instead of the xApp Python Template. Instead of having template Python files, we now have a full xApp Python Library, which abstracts the interfaces towards dRAX and dRAX RIC. More info can be found in the xApp Framework In-depth and xApp Library In-depth . Added new xApp Configuration API. More information can be found in the xApp Configuration In-depth section. Changed ⚓︎ Updated the Workflows to add more options for easier development cycles. More info can be seen in the Quick guide , Development Workflows and Build your own xApp Dev Environment sections. As the new xApp Library is in place, all the previous abstractions of the interfaces are there, however, there are syntax changes. More info can be found in the xApp Library In-depth section. Updated the xApp API structure. More information can be found in the xApp Configuration In-depth section. The programmable approach to configuring the xApp has changed. More info can be found in the xApps Lifecycle In-depth section. The xApp Helm Chart has been updated to incorporate the changes above. More info can be found in the xApp Helm Chart In-Depth . Removed ⚓︎ The xApp API has been removed as a separate Docker image. It is now integrated in the xApp Library and part of the xApp Core. More information can be found in the xApp REST API section. Notes ⚓︎ In the Appendix: Conversion from the xApp Framework to the xApp Library section, we have summarized how to upgrade from the previous xApp Framework version 0.4.0 and 1.0.0 to the new 2.0.0.

docs.title: Version history

docs.text: Added xApp Library instead of the xApp Python Template. Instead of having template Python files, we now have a full xApp Python Library, which abstracts the interfaces towards dRAX and dRAX RIC. More info can be found in the xApp Framework In-depth and xApp Library In-depth . Added new xApp Configuration API. More information can be found in the xApp Configuration In-depth section.
docs.title: Added

docs.text: Updated the Workflows to add more options for easier development cycles. More info can be seen in the Quick guide , Development Workflows and Build your own xApp Dev Environment sections. As the new xApp Library is in place, all the previous abstractions of the interfaces are there, however, there are syntax changes. More info can be found in the xApp Library In-depth section. Updated the xApp API structure. More information can be found in the xApp Configuration In-depth section. The programmable approach to configuring the xApp has changed. More info can be found in the xApps Lifecycle In-depth section. The xApp Helm Chart has been updated to incorporate the changes above. More info can be found in the xApp Helm Chart In-Depth .
docs.title: Changed

docs.text: The xApp API has been removed as a separate Docker image. It is now integrated in the xApp Library and part of the xApp Core. More information can be found in the xApp REST API section.
docs.title: Removed

docs.text: In the Appendix: Conversion from the xApp Framework to the xApp Library section, we have summarized how to upgrade from the previous xApp Framework version 0.4.0 and 1.0.0 to the new 2.0.0.
docs.title: Notes

docs.text: Heartbeats ⚓︎ Description : Both the Layer 2 and Layer3 of each cell send out heartbeats to report that they are alive. The Layer 2 heartbeats has the following format: Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.4g.ric.raw.service_discovery { "ENB": <string>, "ueDraxId": <string>, "ueRicId": <string>, "EnbL2ServiceHeartbeat": { "HeartbeatInfo": { "ComponentId": <string>, "DatastoreAvailable": <bool>, "Interval": <uint> } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "timestamp": <int> } The Layer 3 heartbeats have a similar format: Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.4g.ric.raw.service_discovery { "ENB": <string>, "ueDraxId": <string>, "ueRicId": <string>, "EnbL3ServiceHeartbeat": { "HeartbeatInfo": { "ComponentId": <string>, "DatastoreAvailable": <bool>, "Interval": <uint> } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "timestamp": <int> } Network state ⚓︎ Description : This message publishes the network state of the eNodeB, cell and UEs connected to the cell. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.4g.ric.raw.network_state { "configurationState": { "items": { "enb-id": "<uint32>", "local-cell-id": "<uint32>", "tracking-area-code": "<uint16>", "cell-id": "<uint32>", "good-one-pps-required": "<bool>", "admin-state": "<AdminState>", "op-state": "<OpState>", "rf-tx-status": "<RfTxStatus>", "physical-cell-id": "<uint16>", "downlink-earfcn": "<uint16>", "downlink-bandwidth": "<uint8>", "reference-signal-power": "<int8>", "frequency-band-indicator": "<FrequencyBandIndicator>", "prach-root-sequence-index": "<uint16>", "plmn-list": [ "<string>", ], "mme-set-list": [ "<string64>", ], "serial-number": "<string64>", "gnss-status": "<GnssStatus", "longitude": "<int32>", "latitude": "<int32>", "altitude": "<int32>" }, "ueState": { "items": { "inRange": { "items": <uint64> }, "servingCell": "<string>", "timestamp": <uint64> } } } } Enumeration description : Enum Type: AdminState Enum Values: locked unlocked Enum Type: OpState Enum Values: enabled disabled Enum Type: RfTxStatus Enum Values: on-air off-air Enum Type: FrequencyBandIndicator Enum Values: band-3 band-7 band-14 band-38 band-40 band-42 band-43 band-48 Enum Type: GnssStatus Enum Values: not-yet-available available UE Measurements ⚓︎ Description : If periodic reporting is enabled in the 4G Radio Controller, the UEs will be instructed to send periodic measurements. These measurements contain the RSRP and RSRQ value from the UE to its serving cell, as well as a maximum of 8 neighbouring cells. Each measurement to a specific cell is sent as a separate message. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.4g.ric.raw.ue_measurements { "ENB": <string>, "CELL": <string>, "UE": <string>, "ueDraxId": <string>, "ueRicId": <string>, "Rc4gUeMeasurement": { "UniqueRicId": <string>, "CellId": <string>, "AttachedCellId": <string>, "Rsrp": <uint>, "Rsrq": <uint>, "EllipsoidPointR10": { "EncodedAsn1Length": <uint>, "EncodedAsn1Body": <string> }, "EllipsoidPointWithAltitudeR10": { "EncodedAsn1Length": <uint>, "EncodedAsn1Body": <string> }, "HorizontalVelocityR10": { "EncodedAsn1Length": <uint>, "EncodedAsn1Body": <string> }, "GnssTodMsecR10": { "EncodedAsn1Length": <uint>, "EncodedAsn1Body": <string> } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "timestamp": <int> } L2 Stats ⚓︎ Description : The dRAX RIC also reports the downlink and uplink L2 stats of the UEs in the network. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.4g.ric.raw.ue_measurements { "ENB": <string>, "CELL": <string>, "UE": <string>, "ueDraxId": <string>, "ueRicId": <string>, "EnbStatsL2StatsValues": { "Report": { "DschThroughput": <uint>, "UschThroughput": <uint>, "DownlinkBler": <uint>, "UplinkBler": <uint>, "TimingAdvance": <uint>, "UlSinr": <uint> } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "timestamp": <int> } CQI ⚓︎ Description : The dRAX RIC also supports retrieving the CQI report of the UE to its serving cell. You can get the CQI value from each subband as well as the wideband CQI value. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.4g.ric.raw.ue_measurements { "ENB": <string>, "CELL": <string>, "UE": <string>, "ueDraxId": <string>, "ueRicId": <string>, "EnbStatsCqiReportValues": { "Report": { "WidebandCqi": <uint>, "CodeblockId": <uint>, "CqiList": { "0": <uint> }, "CqiListSize": <uint>, "RankIndication": <uint>, "TransmissionMode": <uint>, "UeEdge": <uint> } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "timestamp": <int> }

docs.text: Description : Both the Layer 2 and Layer3 of each cell send out heartbeats to report that they are alive. The Layer 2 heartbeats has the following format: Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.4g.ric.raw.service_discovery { "ENB": <string>, "ueDraxId": <string>, "ueRicId": <string>, "EnbL2ServiceHeartbeat": { "HeartbeatInfo": { "ComponentId": <string>, "DatastoreAvailable": <bool>, "Interval": <uint> } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "timestamp": <int> } The Layer 3 heartbeats have a similar format: Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.4g.ric.raw.service_discovery { "ENB": <string>, "ueDraxId": <string>, "ueRicId": <string>, "EnbL3ServiceHeartbeat": { "HeartbeatInfo": { "ComponentId": <string>, "DatastoreAvailable": <bool>, "Interval": <uint> } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "timestamp": <int> }

docs.text: Description : If periodic reporting is enabled in the 4G Radio Controller, the UEs will be instructed to send periodic measurements. These measurements contain the RSRP and RSRQ value from the UE to its serving cell, as well as a maximum of 8 neighbouring cells. Each measurement to a specific cell is sent as a separate message. docs.text: Beacons ⚓︎ DU beacon info ⚓︎ Description : This message gives information about the DUs connected to the CU-CP and their operational state (including [3GPP 38.473] served cell information). Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.5g.ric.raw.cu_state { "CuCpDuBeaconInfo": { "GnbId": <uint>, "ServiceInfo": <string>, "DuList": { "items": { "0": { "GnbDuId": <string>, "State": "<DuState>", "ServedCellList": { "items": { "0": { "State": "<CellState>", "NrCgi": { "NrCellId": <string>, "PlmnId": { "items": { "0": <uint> } } }, "Pci": <uint>, "OptionalFivegSTac": { "Present": <bool>, "FivegSTac": { "items": { "0": <uint> } } }, "ServedPlmns": { "items": { "0": { "PlmnIdentity": { "items": { "0": <uint> } }, "TaiSlicedSupportList": { "items": { "0": { "SNssai": { "SST": <uint>, "SD": { "items": { "0": <uint> } } } } } } } } }, "CellGuid": <string> } } }, "DuGuid": <string> } } } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "spanContext__": <string> } Enumeration description : Enum Type: DuState Enum Values: DUSTATE_NON_OPERATIONAL DUSTATE_NON_OPERATIONAL_FAILURE DUSTATE_OPERATIONAL Enum Type: CellState Enum Values: CELLSTATE_NOT_SUPPORTED CELLSTATE_ACTIVATING CELLSTATE_DEACTIVATING CELLSTATE_RESOURCE_UNAVAIL CELLSTATE_ACTIVATION_FAILED CELLSTATE_ACTIVATED CU-UP beacon info ⚓︎ Description : This message gives information about the CU-UPs connected to the CU-CP and their operation state. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.5g.ric.raw.cu_state { "CuCpCuupBeaconInfo": { "GnbId": <uint>, "ServiceInfo": <string>, "CuUpList": { "items": { "0": { "GnbCuupId": <string>, "State": "<CuupState>", "SupportedPlmns": { "items": { "0": { "PlmnIdentity": { "items": { "0": <uint> } }, "SliceSupportList": { "items": { "0": { "SNssai": { "SST": <uint>, "SD": { "items": { "0": <uint> } } } } } } } } }, "CuupGuid": <string> } } } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "spanContext__": <string> } Enumeration description : Enum Type: CuupState Enum Values: CUUPSTATE_OPERATIONAL CUUPSTATE_NON_OPERATIONAL_FAILURE AMF beacon info ⚓︎ Description : This message gives information about the AMFs connected to the CU-CP. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.5g.ric.raw.cu_state { "CuCpAmfBeaconInfo": { "GnbId": <uint>, "ServiceInfo": <string>, "AmfList": { "items": { "0": { "AmfName": <string>, "State": "<AmfState>", "AmfIpaddress": <string>, "SupportedPlmns": { "items": { "0": { "PlmnIdentity": { "items": { "0": <uint> } }, "SliceSupportList": { "items": { "0": { "SNssai": { "SST": <uint>, "SD": { "items": { "0": <uint> } } } } } } } } }, "AmfGuid": <string> } } } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "spanContext__": <string> } Enumeration description : Enum Type: AmfState Enum Values: AMFSTATE_NOT_CONNECTED AMFSTATE_NOT_CONNECTED_FAILURE AMFSTATE_CONNECTED Measurements ⚓︎ UE Measurements ⚓︎ Description : These measurements contain the RSRP and RSRQ periodic measurements from serving cell. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.5g.ric.raw.ue_measurements { "ENB": <string>, "DU": <string>, "CELL": <string>, "UE": <string>, "RrcMeasurementReportResultInfo": { "GnbCuCpUeId": <uint>, "Timestamp": <string>, "ServingCellInfo": { "NrCgi": { "NrCellId": <string>, "PlmnId": { "items": { "0": <uint> } } }, "SsbRsrpResult": <uint>, "SsbRsrpResultPresent": <bool>, "SsbRsrqResult": <uint>, "SsbRsrqResultPresent": <bool>, "SsbSinrResult": <uint>, "SsbSinrResultPresent": <bool> }, "NumberOfIncludedCells": <uint>, "CellInfo": { "0": { "PhyCellId": <uint>, "NeighbourCellInfo": { "NrCgi": { "NrCellId": <string>, "PlmnId": { "items": { "0": <uint> } } }, "SsbRsrpResult": <uint>, "SsbRsrpResultPresent": <bool>, "SsbRsrqResult": <uint>, "SsbRsrqResultPresent": <bool>, "SsbSinrResult": <uint>, "SsbSinrResultPresent": <bool> } } } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "spanContext__": <string> } PM stats ⚓︎ RRC stats ⚓︎ Description : This message gives a list of raw PM counter values in CU-CP Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.5g.ric.raw.pm_counters { "PmReportingCountersListData": { "items": { "0": { "CounterId": "<CounterIdEnum>", "InstanceType": "<InstanceTypeEnum>", "InstanceId": <string>, "ValueList": { "items": { "0": { "_key": <uint>, "_val": <uint> } } } } } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "spanContext__": <string> } Enumeration description : Enum Type: CounterIdEnum Enum Values: RRC_CONNECTION_EST_ATTEMPT_ID RRC_CONNECTION_SUCC_ID REQ_INTRA_GNB_HANDOVER_EXECUTIONS_ID SUCC_INTRA_GNB_HANDOVER_EXECUTIONS_ID DL_GTP_THP_ID DL_GTP_THP_SAMPLES_ID UL_GTP_THP_ID UL_GTP_THP_SAMPLES_ID MAX_NUMBER_COUNTERS Enum Type: InstanceTypeEnum Enum Values: NONE_TYPE CELL_TYPE AMF_TYPE UE_TYPE SSB_FREQ_TYPE QOS_TYPE SNSSAI_TYPE INVALID_TYPE CU-CP Throughput stats ⚓︎ Description : This message gives a list of DL/UL GTP throughput counters at CU-CP. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.5g.ric.raw.pm_counters { "PmReportingCucpCounterData": { "ReportingNodeId": <string>, "CounterList": { "items": { "0": { "CounterId": "<CucpCounterIdEnum>", "InstanceType": "<InstanceTypeEnum>", "InstanceId": <string>, "ValueList": { "items": { "0": { "_key": <uint>, "_val": <uint> } } } } } } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "spanContext__": <string> } Enumeration description : Enum Type: CucpCounterIdEnum Enum Values: RRC_CONNECTION_EST_ATTEMPT RRC_CONNECTION_SUCC REQ_INTRA_GNB_HANDOVER_EXECUTIONS SUCC_INTRA_GNB_HANDOVER_EXECUTIONS MEAN_NUMBER_OF_RRC_CONNECTIONS MAXIMUM_NUMBER_OF_RRC_CONNECTIONS NUMBER_OF_PDU_SESSIONS_REQUESTED_TO_SETUP NUMBER_OF_PDU_SESSIONS_FAILED_TO_SETUP SS_RSRP_DISTRIBUTION_PER_SSB NUMBER_OF_CUCP_COUNTERS Enum Type: InstanceTypeEnum Enum Values: NONE_TYPE CELL_TYPE AMF_TYPE UE_TYPE SSB_FREQ_TYPE QOS_TYPE SNSSAI_TYPE INVALID_TYPE CU-UP Throughput stats ⚓︎ Description : This message gives a list of DL/UL GTP throughput counters at CU-UP. Kafka topic : accelleran.drax.5g.ric.raw.pm_counters { "PmReportingCuupCounterData": { "ReportingNodeId": <string>, "CounterList": { "items": { "0": { "CounterId": "<CuupCounterIdEnum>", "InstanceType": "<InstanceTypeEnum>", "InstanceId": <string>, "ValueList": { "items": { "0": { "_key": <uint>, "_val": <uint> } } } } } } }, "tlpublishTime__": <string>, "spanContext__": <string> } Enumeration description : Enum Type: CuupCounterIdEnum Enum Values: DL_GTP_THP UL_GTP_THP DRB_PACKET_LOSS_UL_QOS DRB_PACKET_LOSS_UL_SNSSAI DRB_PDCP_PACKET_DROP_RATE_DL_QOS DRB_PDCP_PACKET_DROP_RATE_DL_SNSSAI AVERAGE_DELAY_DL_IN_CUUP_QOS AVERAGE_DELAY_DL_IN_CUUP_SNSSAI DISTRIBUTION_OF_DELAY_DL_IN_CUUP_QOS DISTRIBUTION_OF_DELAY_DL_IN_CUUP_SNSSAI NUMBER_OF_CUUP_COUNTERS Enum Type: InstanceTypeEnum Enum Values: NONE_TYPE CELL_TYPE AMF_TYPE UE_TYPE SSB_FREQ_TYPE QOS_TYPE SNSSAI_TYPE INVALID_TYPE

MAX_NUM_OF_XPATHS elements of type XpathItem FilterModeType ⚓︎ Specifies how you want filterinf done Name Number Description Filter_PREFIX 0 If the XPATH matches the beginning the filter will pass Filter_FULL 1 The XPATH must match exactly in order to pass Filter_LEAF 2 The XPATH must match exactly and the leaf must be matching in order to pass Filter_PREFIX_IGNORE_KEYS 3 If the XPATH matches the beginning the filter will pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Filter_FULL_IGNORE_KEYS 4 The XPATH must match exactly in order to pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Filter_LEAF_IGNORE_KEYS 5 The XPATH must match exactly and the leaf must be matching in order to pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Operation ⚓︎ Specifies what happend (Create Update Delete) Name Number Description Operation_UNKNOWN 0 The operation could not be determined Operation_CREATE 1 A create was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_UPDATE 2 An update was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_DELETE 3 A delete was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_ALL 4 value to indicate that all operations are good Origin ⚓︎ Specifies where the modification came from Name Number Description Origin_APP 0 Modification was done by the application Origin_NETCONF 1 Modification was done via NetConf genDSC.proto ⚓︎ It is billateral knowledge between caller and callee to give meaning to this response RESULT_INPROGRESS 3 The callee indicates the recption of the request. Responses will be send asynchroniously RESULT_OTHER 4 It is billateral knowledge between caller and callee to give meaning to this response RESULT_NO_RESULTS 5 Indicates that no results where returnes, this is typically used in datastore operations RESULT_MAX 6 Place holder to indicate the maximun number of enum values. If a value is received that is higher than RESULT_MAX, the result should be considered FAILURE GuidType ⚓︎ Enumeration for guid ids. Name Number Description GuidType_Invalid 0 Please provide a description for GuidType_Invalid GuidType_Enb 1 Please provide a description for GuidType_Enb GuidType_Cell 2 Please provide a description for GuidType_Cell GuidType_Ue 3 Please provide a description for GuidType_Ue GuidType_CuUp 4 Please provide a description for GuidType_CuUp GuidType_Du 5 Please provide a description for GuidType_Du GuidType_Amf 6 Please provide a description for GuidType_Amf GuidType_Ng 7 Please provide a description for GuidType_Ng ServiceType ⚓︎ enum that contains an overview of all service types used by beacon module Name Number Description SERVICETYPE_INVALID 0 Please provide a description for SERVICETYPE_INVALID SERVICETYPE_LAYER2 1 Please provide a description for SERVICETYPE_LAYER2 SERVICETYPE_LAYER3 2 Please provide a description for SERVICETYPE_LAYER3 SERVICETYPE_ORAN 3 Please provide a description for SERVICETYPE_ORAN SERVICETYPE_ENODEB 4 Please provide a description for SERVICETYPE_ENODEB SERVICETYPE_CUCP 5 Please provide a description for SERVICETYPE_CUCP genGNBCUCPTypes.proto ⚓︎ GnbCuCp ⚓︎ Grouping for the class representing a gNB-CU-CP. Field Type Label Description GnbId uint32 optional The gNB ID part of the Global gNB ID. PlmnId string optional 5 or 6 digit PLMN code (MCC and MNC) of the PLMN to which the gNB belongs. Forms part of the gNB's Global gNB ID as used in NGAP messages. GnbIdLength uint32 optional The length of the bit string representation of the gNB ID. GnbCuCpName string optional Human readable name of the gNB-CU-CP. If configured, this is sent to a gNB-CU-UP, gNB-DU and AMF during the E1, F1 and NG Setup procedures respectively. AdminState PBAccGenTypes.AdminState optional Administrative state. Value 'unlocked' means that the gNB is permitted to serve users. Value 'locked' means that the gNB is prohibited from serving users. In the 'locked' state, all of the gNB's cells will be off air. OpState PBAccGenTypes.OpState optional Operational state. Value 'disabled' means that the gNB is totally inoperable and unable to provide service to users. Value 'enabled' means that the gNB is partially or fully operable and available for use. NbrOfAllowedCipheringAlgorithm uint32 optional automatically added field for "allowed-ciphering-algorithm" list AllowedCipheringAlgorithm PBAcc5GTypes.CipheringAlgorithm repeated List of 5G ciphering algorithms allowed to be used in the gNB, in decreasing order of preference, i.e. most preferred algorithm first. If nea0 is included, it should be the last entry in the list. Ciphering algorithms that are not supported by the gNB must not be included in the list. NbrOfAllowedIntegrityAlgorithm uint32 optional automatically added field for "allowed-integrity-algorithm" list AllowedIntegrityAlgorithm PBAcc5GTypes.IntegrityAlgorithm repeated List of 5G integrity algorithms allowed to be used in the gNB, in decreasing order of preference, i.e. most preferred algorithm first. nia0 should only be included in deployments where support of unauthenticated emergency calling is a regulatory requirement, and should be the last entry in the list. Integrity algorithms that are not supported by the gNB must not be included in the list. E1LinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.E1LinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of SCTP on E1 interfaces. F1CLinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.F1CLinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of SCTP on F1-c interfaces. NbrOfOperator uint32 optional automatically added field for "operator" list Operator Operator repeated Data relating to an operator who makes use of the gNB's services and resources. There may be more than one operator in the case of RAN sharing. NgCLink ⚓︎ Grouping for the class representing an NG-C link. Field Type Label Description DestAddress string optional IP address or FQDN of the AMF at the far end of the link. OpState PBAccGenTypes.OpState optional Value 'enabled' means that an SCTP association has been established and an NG Setup procedure has been successfully performed with the AMF at the far end of the link; otherwise the value is 'disabled'. DefaultAmf bool optional Corresponds to default AMF as specified in [3GPP 23.501] AmfName string optional This is the value of the AMF Name received in an NGAP message from the AMF at the far end of the link. Operator ⚓︎ Grouping for the class representing an operator of a gNB. Field Type Label Description OperatorId string optional A string that uniquely identifies the operator. NgCLinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.NgCLinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of NG-C links to AMFs belonging to the operator. NbrOfNgCLink uint32 optional automatically added field for "ng-c-link" list NgCLink NgCLink repeated Represents a logical link on the NG-C interface between the gNB-CU-CP and an AMF. genGNBCUUPTypes.proto ⚓︎ GnbCuUp ⚓︎ Represents a gNB-CU-UP. Field Type Label Description UpIntegrityProtectionEnabled bool optional Value true means that the CU-UP will activate integrity protection of DRBs if requested, subject to the specified integrity algorithm being supported; false means that it will not activate integrity protection of DRBs under any circumstances. This determines how the CU-UP handles receipt of a Security Indication IE with the Integrity Protection Indication IE set to 'required' or 'preferred', over E1. UpCipheringEnabled bool optional Value true means that the CU-UP will activate confidentiality protection of DRBs if requested, subject to the specified ciphering algorithm being supported; false means that it will not activate confidentiality protection of DRBs under any circumstances. This determines how the CU-UP handles receipt of a Security Indication IE with the Confidentiality Protection Indication IE set to 'required' or 'preferred', over E1. genGnbController.proto ⚓︎ docs.text: Defines parameters that are configurable for all reportConfigs. Field Type Label Description MaxReportCells uint32 optional The maximum number of neighbour cells to be reported in the Measurement Report message. ReportInterval ReportInterval optional The interval between periodic reports. Can be applied to triggerType 'event' as well as 'periodical'. ReportAmount ReportAmount optional The number of measurement reports required. Can be applied to triggerType 'event' as well as 'periodical'. FilterCoeffRsrp PBAcc5GTypes.FilterCoefficient optional Filter coefficient for RSRP measurements at the UE FilterCoeffRsrq PBAcc5GTypes.FilterCoefficient optional Filter coefficient for RSRQ measurements at the UE FilterCoeffSinr PBAcc5GTypes.FilterCoefficient optional Filter coefficient for SINR measurements at the UE

docs.text: Specifies how you want filterinf done Name Number Description Filter_PREFIX 0 If the XPATH matches the beginning the filter will pass Filter_FULL 1 The XPATH must match exactly in order to pass Filter_LEAF 2 The XPATH must match exactly and the leaf must be matching in order to pass Filter_PREFIX_IGNORE_KEYS 3 If the XPATH matches the beginning the filter will pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Filter_FULL_IGNORE_KEYS 4 The XPATH must match exactly in order to pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Filter_LEAF_IGNORE_KEYS 5 The XPATH must match exactly and the leaf must be matching in order to pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes)
docs.title: FilterModeType

docs.text: Specifies what happend (Create Update Delete) Name Number Description Operation_UNKNOWN 0 The operation could not be determined Operation_CREATE 1 A create was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_UPDATE 2 An update was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_DELETE 3 A delete was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_ALL 4 value to indicate that all operations are good
docs.title: Operation

docs.text: Specifies where the modification came from Name Number Description Origin_APP 0 Modification was done by the application Origin_NETCONF 1 Modification was done via NetConf

docs.text: Enumeration for common results Extra enumeration values can be added if needed Name Number Description RESULT_SUCCESS 0 Indicates a successful outcome of the requested operation RESULT_FAILURE 1 The operation failed any value returned by the call must be ignored RESULT_PARTIAL_SUCCESS 2 The callee indicates partial success. It is billateral knowledge between caller and callee to give meaning to this response RESULT_INPROGRESS 3 The callee indicates the recption of the request. Responses will be send asynchroniously RESULT_OTHER 4 It is billateral knowledge between caller and callee to give meaning to this response RESULT_NO_RESULTS 5 Indicates that no results where returnes, this is typically used in datastore operations RESULT_MAX 6 Place holder to indicate the maximun number of enum values. If a value is received that is higher than RESULT_MAX, the result should be considered FAILURE
docs.title: CommonResult

docs.text: Grouping for the class representing a gNB-CU-CP. Field Type Label Description GnbId uint32 optional The gNB ID part of the Global gNB ID. PlmnId string optional 5 or 6 digit PLMN code (MCC and MNC) of the PLMN to which the gNB belongs. Forms part of the gNB's Global gNB ID as used in NGAP messages. GnbIdLength uint32 optional The length of the bit string representation of the gNB ID. GnbCuCpName string optional Human readable name of the gNB-CU-CP. If configured, this is sent to a gNB-CU-UP, gNB-DU and AMF during the E1, F1 and NG Setup procedures respectively. AdminState PBAccGenTypes.AdminState optional Administrative state. Value 'unlocked' means that the gNB is permitted to serve users. Value 'locked' means that the gNB is prohibited from serving users. In the 'locked' state, all of the gNB's cells will be off air. OpState PBAccGenTypes.OpState optional Operational state. Value 'disabled' means that the gNB is totally inoperable and unable to provide service to users. Value 'enabled' means that the gNB is partially or fully operable and available for use. NbrOfAllowedCipheringAlgorithm uint32 optional automatically added field for "allowed-ciphering-algorithm" list AllowedCipheringAlgorithm PBAcc5GTypes.CipheringAlgorithm repeated List of 5G ciphering algorithms allowed to be used in the gNB, in decreasing order of preference, i.e. most preferred algorithm first. If nea0 is included, it should be the last entry in the list. Ciphering algorithms that are not supported by the gNB must not be included in the list. NbrOfAllowedIntegrityAlgorithm uint32 optional automatically added field for "allowed-integrity-algorithm" list AllowedIntegrityAlgorithm PBAcc5GTypes.IntegrityAlgorithm repeated List of 5G integrity algorithms allowed to be used in the gNB, in decreasing order of preference, i.e. most preferred algorithm first. nia0 should only be included in deployments where support of unauthenticated emergency calling is a regulatory requirement, and should be the last entry in the list. Integrity algorithms that are not supported by the gNB must not be included in the list. E1LinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.E1LinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of SCTP on E1 interfaces. F1CLinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.F1CLinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of SCTP on F1-c interfaces. NbrOfOperator uint32 optional automatically added field for "operator" list Operator Operator repeated Data relating to an operator who makes use of the gNB's services and resources. There may be more than one operator in the case of RAN sharing.
docs.title: GnbCuCp

docs.text: Grouping for the class representing an NG-C link. Field Type Label Description DestAddress string optional IP address or FQDN of the AMF at the far end of the link. OpState PBAccGenTypes.OpState optional Value 'enabled' means that an SCTP association has been established and an NG Setup procedure has been successfully performed with the AMF at the far end of the link; otherwise the value is 'disabled'. DefaultAmf bool optional Corresponds to default AMF as specified in [3GPP 23.501] AmfName string optional This is the value of the AMF Name received in an NGAP message from the AMF at the far end of the link.
docs.title: NgCLink

docs.text: Grouping for the class representing an operator of a gNB. Field Type Label Description OperatorId string optional A string that uniquely identifies the operator. NgCLinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.NgCLinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of NG-C links to AMFs belonging to the operator. NbrOfNgCLink uint32 optional automatically added field for "ng-c-link" list NgCLink NgCLink repeated Represents a logical link on the NG-C interface between the gNB-CU-CP and an AMF.
docs.title: Operator

docs.text: Represents a gNB-CU-UP. Field Type Label Description UpIntegrityProtectionEnabled bool optional Value true means that the CU-UP will activate integrity protection of DRBs if requested, subject to the specified integrity algorithm being supported; false means that it will not activate integrity protection of DRBs under any circumstances. This determines how the CU-UP handles receipt of a Security Indication IE with the Integrity Protection Indication IE set to 'required' or 'preferred', over E1. UpCipheringEnabled bool optional Value true means that the CU-UP will activate confidentiality protection of DRBs if requested, subject to the specified ciphering algorithm being supported; false means that it will not activate confidentiality protection of DRBs under any circumstances. This determines how the CU-UP handles receipt of a Security Indication IE with the Confidentiality Protection Indication IE set to 'required' or 'preferred', over E1.
docs.title: GnbCuUp

docs.text: Protocol Documentation ⚓︎ genAccelleran5GTypes.proto ⚓︎ E1LinkPolicy ⚓︎ Groups parameters that define the policy relating to the use of E1 links. Field Type Label Description SctpPolicy SctpPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy for the use of SCTP on E1 links. F1CLinkPolicy ⚓︎ Groups parameters that define the policy relating to the use of F1-c links. Field Type Label Description SctpPolicy SctpPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy for the use of SCTP on F1-c links. NgCLinkPolicy ⚓︎ Groups parameters that define the policy relating to the use of NG-C links. Field Type Label Description SctpPolicy SctpPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy for the use of SCTP on NG-C links. NrCellGlobalIdentity ⚓︎ Please provide a description in your YANG file for nr-cell-global-identity Field Type Label Description PlmnIdentity string optional Please provide a description in your YANG file for plmn-identity NrCellIdentity uint64 optional Please provide a description in your YANG file for nr-cell-identity SNssai ⚓︎ Please provide a description in your YANG file for s-nssai Field Type Label Description Sst Sst optional Slice/Service Type. Sd uint32 optional Slice Differentiator. SctpPolicy ⚓︎ Please provide a description in your YANG file for sctp-policy Field Type Label Description InStreams uint32 optional The maximum number of inbound streams that will be accepted. OutStreams uint32 optional The number of outbound streams that will be requested. SsbMtc ⚓︎ Please provide a description in your YANG file for ssb-mtc Field Type Label Description SmtcPeriodicity SsbMtcPeriodicity optional Please provide a description in your YANG file for smtc-periodicity SmtcOffset uint32 optional SSB transmission offset in subframes Duration uint32 optional Please provide a description in your YANG file for duration SupportedPlmnSlices ⚓︎ Groups information about a PLMN and the set of slices supported by that PLMN. Field Type Label Description PlmnId string optional Identifies a PLMN. NbrOfSNssai uint32 optional automatically added field for "s-nssai" list SNssai SNssai repeated Identifies a slice that is supported by the PLMN. CellReselectionSubPriority ⚓︎ indicates a fractional value to be added to the value of cellReselectionPriority to obtain the absolute priority of the concerned carrier frequency for E-UTRA and NR Name Number Description o_2 0 0.2 o_4 1 0.4 o_6 2 0.6 o_8 3 0.8 CipheringAlgorithm ⚓︎ Type definition for 5G ciphering algorithms. Name Number Description cipher_nea0 0 NEA0, the null 5G ciphering algorithm. cipher_128_nea1 1 128-NEA1, the 128-bit SNOW 3G based 5G ciphering algorithm. cipher_128_nea2 2 128-NEA2, the 128-bit AES based 5G ciphering algorithm. cipher_128_nea3 3 128-NEA3, the 128-bit ZUC based 5G ciphering algorithm. EutraAllowedMeasurementBandwidth ⚓︎ The values mbw6, mbw15, mbw25, mbw50, mbw75, mbw100 indicate 6, 15, 25, 50, 75 and 100 resource blocks, respectively Name Number Description mbw6 0 Please provide a description for mbw6 mbw15 1 Please provide a description for mbw15 mbw25 2 Please provide a description for mbw25 mbw50 3 Please provide a description for mbw50 mbw75 4 Please provide a description for mbw75 mbw100 5 Please provide a description for mbw100 FilterCoefficient ⚓︎ Allowed values for filtering coefficient Name Number Description filter_coefficient_unknown 0 Enum equivalent for numeric value unknown filter_coefficient_0 1 Enum equivalent for numeric value 0 filter_coefficient_1 2 Enum equivalent for numeric value 1 filter_coefficient_2 3 Enum equivalent for numeric value 2 filter_coefficient_3 4 Enum equivalent for numeric value 3 filter_coefficient_4 5 Enum equivalent for numeric value 4 filter_coefficient_5 6 Enum equivalent for numeric value 5 filter_coefficient_6 7 Enum equivalent for numeric value 6 filter_coefficient_7 8 Enum equivalent for numeric value 7 filter_coefficient_8 9 Enum equivalent for numeric value 8 filter_coefficient_9 10 Enum equivalent for numeric value 9 filter_coefficient_11 11 Enum equivalent for numeric value 11 filter_coefficient_13 12 Enum equivalent for numeric value 13 filter_coefficient_15 13 Enum equivalent for numeric value 15 filter_coefficient_17 14 Enum equivalent for numeric value 17 filter_coefficient_19 15 Enum equivalent for numeric value 19 IntegrityAlgorithm ⚓︎ Type definition for 5G integrity algorithms. Name Number Description integrity_nia0 0 NIA0, the null 5G integrity algorithm. integrity_128_nia1 1 128-NIA1, the 128-bit SNOW 3G based 5G integrity algorithm. integrity_128_nia2 2 128-NIA2, the 128-bit AES based 5G integrity algorithm. integrity_128_nia3 3 128-NIA3, the 128-bit ZUC based 5G integrity algorithm. XpathItem FilterModeType ⚓︎ Specifies how you want filterinf done Name Number Description Filter_PREFIX 0 If the XPATH matches the beginning the filter will pass Filter_FULL 1 The XPATH must match exactly in order to pass Filter_LEAF 2 The XPATH must match exactly and the leaf must be matching in order to pass Filter_PREFIX_IGNORE_KEYS 3 If the XPATH matches the beginning the filter will pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Filter_FULL_IGNORE_KEYS 4 The XPATH must match exactly in order to pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Filter_LEAF_IGNORE_KEYS 5 The XPATH must match exactly and the leaf must be matching in order to pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Operation ⚓︎ Specifies what happend (Create Update Delete) Name Number Description Operation_UNKNOWN 0 The operation could not be determined Operation_CREATE 1 A create was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_UPDATE 2 An update was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_DELETE 3 A delete was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_ALL 4 value to indicate that all operations are good Origin ⚓︎ Specifies where the modification came from Name Number Responses will be send asynchroniously RESULT_OTHER 4 It is billateral knowledge between caller and callee to give meaning to this response RESULT_NO_RESULTS 5 Indicates that no results where returnes, this is typically used in datastore operations RESULT_MAX 6 Place holder to indicate the maximun number of enum values. Field Type Label Description GnbId uint32 optional The gNB ID part of the Global gNB ID. PlmnId string optional 5 or 6 digit PLMN code (MCC and MNC) of the PLMN to which the gNB belongs. Forms part of the gNB's Global gNB ID as used in NGAP messages. GnbIdLength uint32 optional The length of the bit string representation of the gNB ID. GnbCuCpName string optional Human readable name of the gNB-CU-CP. If configured, this is sent to a gNB-CU-UP, gNB-DU and AMF during the E1, F1 and NG Setup procedures respectively. AdminState PBAccGenTypes.AdminState optional Administrative state. Value 'unlocked' means that the gNB is permitted to serve users. Value 'locked' means that the gNB is prohibited from serving users. In the 'locked' state, all of the gNB's cells will be off air. RlcMode PBAcc5GTypes.RlcMode optional Contains RLC mode entity value. OpState PBAccGenTypes.OpState optional Operational state. Value 'disabled' means that the gNB is totally inoperable and unable to provide service to users. Value 'enabled' means that the gNB is partially or fully operable and available for use. NbrOfAllowedCipheringAlgorithm uint32 optional automatically added field for "allowed-ciphering-algorithm" list AllowedCipheringAlgorithm PBAcc5GTypes.CipheringAlgorithm repeated List of 5G ciphering algorithms allowed to be used in the gNB, in decreasing order of preference, i.e. most preferred algorithm first. If nea0 is included, it should be the last entry in the list. Ciphering algorithms that are not supported by the gNB must not be included in the list. NbrOfAllowedIntegrityAlgorithm uint32 optional automatically added field for "allowed-integrity-algorithm" list AllowedIntegrityAlgorithm PBAcc5GTypes.IntegrityAlgorithm repeated List of 5G integrity algorithms allowed to be used in the gNB, in decreasing order of preference, i.e. most preferred algorithm first. nia0 should only be included in deployments where support of unauthenticated emergency calling is a regulatory requirement, and should be the last entry in the list. Integrity algorithms that are not supported by the gNB must not be included in the list. E1LinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.E1LinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of SCTP on E1 interfaces. F1CLinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.F1CLinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of SCTP on F1-c interfaces. NbrOfOperator uint32 optional automatically added field for "operator" list Operator Operator repeated Data relating to an operator who makes use of the gNB's services and resources. There may be more than one operator in the case of RAN sharing. NgCLink ⚓︎ Grouping for the class representing an NG-C link. Field Type Label Description DestAddress string optional IP address or FQDN of the AMF at the far end of the link. OpState PBAccGenTypes.OpState optional Value 'enabled' means that an SCTP association has been established and an NG Setup procedure has been successfully performed with the AMF at the far end of the link; otherwise the value is 'disabled'. DefaultAmf bool optional Corresponds to default AMF as specified in [3GPP 23.501] AmfName string optional This is the value of the AMF Name received in an NGAP message from the AMF at the far end of the link. Operator ⚓︎ Grouping for the class representing an operator of a gNB. Field Type Label Description OperatorId string optional A string that uniquely identifies the operator. NgCLinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.NgCLinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of NG-C links to AMFs belonging to the operator. NbrOfNgCLink uint32 optional automatically added field for "ng-c-link" list NgCLink NgCLink repeated Represents a logical link on the NG-C interface between the gNB-CU-CP and an AMF. genGNBCUUPTypes.proto ⚓︎ GnbCuUp ⚓︎ Represents a gNB-CU-UP. Field Type Label Description UpIntegrityProtectionEnabled bool optional Value true means that the CU-UP will activate integrity protection of DRBs if requested, subject to the specified integrity algorithm being supported; false means that it will not activate integrity protection of DRBs under any circumstances. This determines how the CU-UP handles receipt of a Security Indication IE with the Integrity Protection Indication IE set to 'required' or 'preferred', over E1. UpCipheringEnabled bool optional Value true means that the CU-UP will activate confidentiality protection of DRBs if requested, subject to the specified ciphering algorithm being supported; false means that it will not activate confidentiality protection of DRBs under any circumstances. This determines how the CU-UP handles receipt of a Security Indication IE with the Confidentiality Protection Indication IE set to 'required' or 'preferred', over E1. genGnbController.proto ⚓︎ docs.text: Defines parameters that are configurable for all A3 report configurations (other than those in report-config-common). Field Type Label Description A3Offset int32 optional The offset value to be used in an A3 report configuration. TriggerQuantity TriggerQuantity optional Indicates whether A3 is to be based on RSRP or RSRQ or SINR measurements. Hysteresis uint32 optional The hysteresis parameter used in the entering and leaving conditions for an A3 event triggered reporting condition. TimeToTrigger TimeToTrigger optional The time during which the conditions for an A3 event need to be met in order to trigger a measurement report.

docs.text: Defines parameters that are configurable for all reportConfigs. Field Type Label Description MaxReportCells uint32 optional The maximum number of neighbour cells to be reported in the Measurement Report message. ReportInterval ReportInterval optional The interval between periodic reports. Can be applied to triggerType 'event' as well as 'periodical'. ReportAmount ReportAmount optional The number of measurement reports required. Can be applied to triggerType 'event' as well as 'periodical'. FilterCoeffRsrp PBAcc5GTypes.FilterCoefficient optional Filter coefficient for RSRP measurements at the UE FilterCoeffRsrq PBAcc5GTypes.FilterCoefficient optional Filter coefficient for RSRQ measurements at the UE FilterCoeffSinr PBAcc5GTypes.FilterCoefficient optional Filter coefficient for SINR measurements at the UE

docs.text: Please provide a description in your YANG file for registration-request-object Field Type Label Description UserId string optional The UR-ID per [n.12] R2-SRR-02 conformant per section 2.2 of [n.18]. FccId string optional The FCC certification identifier of the CBSD. It is a string of up to 19 characters as described in [n.22] CbsdSerialNumber string optional A serial number assigned to the CBSD by the CBSD device manufacturer having a maximum length of 64 octets. This serial number shall be unique for every CBSD instance sharing the same value of fccId. Each CBSD has a single CBSD Antenna (Ref. definition in section 4) and has a single cbsdSerialNumber. CallSign string optional A device identifier provided by the FCC per [n.13]. CbsdCategory CbsdCategory optional Device Category of the CBSD. Allowed values are 'A' or 'B' as defined in Part 96 CbsdInfo CbsdInfo optional Information about this CBSD model. AirInterface AirInterfaceObject optional A data object that includes information on the air interface technology of the CBSD. InstallationParam InstallationParamObject optional A data object that includes information on CBSD installation. MeasurementCapabilities MeasurementCapabilitiesObject optional The array of string lists measurement reporting capabilities of the CBSD. The permitted enumerations are specified in [n.21]. GroupingParam GroupingParam optional An array of data objects that includes information on CBSD grouping. CpiSignatureData CpiSignatureData optional The CPI is vouching for the parameters included in this object. In addition, the digital signature for these parameters is included.
docs.title: RegistrationRequestObject

docs.text: Specifies how you want filterinf done Name Number Description Filter_PREFIX 0 If the XPATH matches the beginning the filter will pass Filter_FULL 1 The XPATH must match exactly in order to pass Filter_LEAF 2 The XPATH must match exactly and the leaf must be matching in order to pass Filter_PREFIX_IGNORE_KEYS 3 If the XPATH matches the beginning the filter will pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Filter_FULL_IGNORE_KEYS 4 The XPATH must match exactly in order to pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes) Filter_LEAF_IGNORE_KEYS 5 The XPATH must match exactly and the leaf must be matching in order to pass (after the path was cleaned of keys attributes)
docs.title: FilterModeType

docs.text: Specifies what happend (Create Update Delete) Name Number Description Operation_UNKNOWN 0 The operation could not be determined Operation_CREATE 1 A create was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_UPDATE 2 An update was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_DELETE 3 A delete was done for the given xpath/leaf Operation_ALL 4 value to indicate that all operations are good
docs.title: Operation

docs.text: Specifies where the modification came from Name Number Description Origin_APP 0 Modification was done by the application Origin_NETCONF 1 Modification was done via NetConf

docs.text: Enumeration for common results Extra enumeration values can be added if needed Name Number Description RESULT_SUCCESS 0 Indicates a successful outcome of the requested operation RESULT_FAILURE 1 The operation failed any value returned by the call must be ignored RESULT_PARTIAL_SUCCESS 2 The callee indicates partial success. It is billateral knowledge between caller and callee to give meaning to this response RESULT_INPROGRESS 3 The callee indicates the recption of the request. Responses will be send asynchroniously RESULT_OTHER 4 It is billateral knowledge between caller and callee to give meaning to this response RESULT_NO_RESULTS 5 Indicates that no results where returnes, this is typically used in datastore operations RESULT_MAX 6 Place holder to indicate the maximun number of enum values. If a value is received that is higher than RESULT_MAX, the result should be considered FAILURE
docs.title: CommonResult

docs.text: Grouping for the class representing a gNB-CU-CP. Field Type Label Description GnbId uint32 optional The gNB ID part of the Global gNB ID. PlmnId string optional 5 or 6 digit PLMN code (MCC and MNC) of the PLMN to which the gNB belongs. Forms part of the gNB's Global gNB ID as used in NGAP messages. GnbIdLength uint32 optional The length of the bit string representation of the gNB ID. GnbCuCpName string optional Human readable name of the gNB-CU-CP. If configured, this is sent to a gNB-CU-UP, gNB-DU and AMF during the E1, F1 and NG Setup procedures respectively. AdminState PBAccGenTypes.AdminState optional Administrative state. Value 'unlocked' means that the gNB is permitted to serve users. Value 'locked' means that the gNB is prohibited from serving users. In the 'locked' state, all of the gNB's cells will be off air. RlcMode PBAcc5GTypes.RlcMode optional Contains RLC mode entity value. OpState PBAccGenTypes.OpState optional Operational state. Value 'disabled' means that the gNB is totally inoperable and unable to provide service to users. Value 'enabled' means that the gNB is partially or fully operable and available for use. NbrOfAllowedCipheringAlgorithm uint32 optional automatically added field for "allowed-ciphering-algorithm" list AllowedCipheringAlgorithm PBAcc5GTypes.CipheringAlgorithm repeated List of 5G ciphering algorithms allowed to be used in the gNB, in decreasing order of preference, i.e. most preferred algorithm first. If nea0 is included, it should be the last entry in the list. Ciphering algorithms that are not supported by the gNB must not be included in the list. NbrOfAllowedIntegrityAlgorithm uint32 optional automatically added field for "allowed-integrity-algorithm" list AllowedIntegrityAlgorithm PBAcc5GTypes.IntegrityAlgorithm repeated List of 5G integrity algorithms allowed to be used in the gNB, in decreasing order of preference, i.e. most preferred algorithm first. nia0 should only be included in deployments where support of unauthenticated emergency calling is a regulatory requirement, and should be the last entry in the list. Integrity algorithms that are not supported by the gNB must not be included in the list. E1LinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.E1LinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of SCTP on E1 interfaces. F1CLinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.F1CLinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of SCTP on F1-c interfaces. NbrOfOperator uint32 optional automatically added field for "operator" list Operator Operator repeated Data relating to an operator who makes use of the gNB's services and resources. There may be more than one operator in the case of RAN sharing.
docs.title: GnbCuCp

docs.text: Grouping for the class representing an NG-C link. Field Type Label Description DestAddress string optional IP address or FQDN of the AMF at the far end of the link. OpState PBAccGenTypes.OpState optional Value 'enabled' means that an SCTP association has been established and an NG Setup procedure has been successfully performed with the AMF at the far end of the link; otherwise the value is 'disabled'. DefaultAmf bool optional Corresponds to default AMF as specified in [3GPP 23.501] AmfName string optional This is the value of the AMF Name received in an NGAP message from the AMF at the far end of the link.
docs.title: NgCLink

docs.text: Grouping for the class representing an operator of a gNB. Field Type Label Description OperatorId string optional A string that uniquely identifies the operator. NgCLinkPolicy PBAcc5GTypes.NgCLinkPolicy optional Contains parameters that define the policy relating to the use of NG-C links to AMFs belonging to the operator. NbrOfNgCLink uint32 optional automatically added field for "ng-c-link" list NgCLink NgCLink repeated Represents a logical link on the NG-C interface between the gNB-CU-CP and an AMF.
docs.title: Operator

docs.text: Represents a gNB-CU-UP. Field Type Label Description UpIntegrityProtectionEnabled bool optional Value true means that the CU-UP will activate integrity protection of DRBs if requested, subject to the specified integrity algorithm being supported; false means that it will not activate integrity protection of DRBs under any circumstances. This determines how the CU-UP handles receipt of a Security Indication IE with the Integrity Protection Indication IE set to 'required' or 'preferred', over E1. UpCipheringEnabled bool optional Value true means that the CU-UP will activate confidentiality protection of DRBs if requested, subject to the specified ciphering algorithm being supported; false means that it will not activate confidentiality protection of DRBs under any circumstances. This determines how the CU-UP handles receipt of a Security Indication IE with the Confidentiality Protection Indication IE set to 'required' or 'preferred', over E1.
docs.title: GnbCuUp

docs.text: Gives general information of a UPS instance. This info will be used by the load balancer to add and remove BPF forward filters to the correct interface. Containers get assigned a virtual ethernet interface to communicate with the host. This interface has a Container part side and a host side. The info provided here is the host ide ifIndex. docs.text: Appendix: Conversion from the xApp Framework to the xApp Library ⚓︎ Due to the kind of big changes between the different versions of the xApp Framework/Library, this appendix handles how to convert between them. xApp Configuration ⚓︎ The xApp Configuration has undergone a big change from the previous version of the xApp framework. The xApp Configuration was generated by the xApp helm Chart, by generating the xapp-configuration.json. In the new xApp Framework, the developer is in charge of creating the xapp_metadata.json file, which contains metadata and configuration options, including their default values. Only when you need to change the configuration from their default values, you can use the xApp helm Chart values.yaml to do so. This is explained in the following subsection. The developer needs to copy all the configuration options that were defined in the xApp Helm Chart values.yaml under the xappConfig key, to the xapp_metadata.json, keeping in mind the xapp_metadata.json format, which can be seen in the xApp Metadata section. The xapp_endpoints.json configuration file is generated by the xApp Helm Chart. Its content can bee seen under the xappEndpoints key in the xApp Helm Chart values.yaml. These are the normal dRAX RIC endpoints required for the xApp Framework to work properly. In case you need to add other endpoints, you can check the xApp Endpoints section. xApp Helm Chart ⚓︎ We recommend that you pick up the new xApp Helm Chart from the xApp Framework repository, in the example folder. Then, edit the values.yaml file as follows. The image key: As with the previous version, edit the image key to point to your own xApp Core Docker image, including the repository and tag fields under image. There is no particular change here, but we note it as a general change required. The xappConfig key: You will notice a change in the way we define the xApp Configuration options. First of all, part of the previous configuration options are moved to the xapp_endpoints.json, explained earlier. The rest of the configuration options are moved to xapp_metadata.json. The xapp_metadata.json also holds the default values of the xApp Configuration options. The new xappConfig key in the values.yaml is to change those config options on deployment time only if needed. Hence, by default the xappConfig is set as an empty list. If you need to change the default values, not that the xappConfig is now a list instead of a dictionary. For example, what was previously: xappConfig: - name: 'LOG_LEVEL' type: int value: 20 Is now: xappConfig: LOG_LEVEL: 20 Main code ⚓︎ In previous versions, the xApp Framework required the developer to modify the run function inside the processor.py file: def run(settings, in_queue, out_queue, data_store): while True: msg = in_queue.get() data = msg['data'] topic = msg['topic'] # handle data In the xApp library this can be rewritten as If __name__ == "__main__": builder = xapp_lib.XAppBuilder("..", absolute=False) builder.metadata("core/xapp_metadata.json") builder.endpoints("config/xapp_endpoints.json") builder.config("config/xapp_config.json") builder.readme("README.md") builder.restapi( [ ("/api/", restapi.MainApiHandler), ("/api/actions", restapi.ActionsHandler), ("/api/request", restapi.RequestHandler), ] ) xapp = builder.build() while True: (topic, data) = xapp.kafka().json().recv_message() # handle data Actions ⚓︎ Most of the functionality from action_taker has been moved to actions, and requires an xapp.nats() as first argument instead of a queue: actions.handover_command(xapp.nats(), handover_cells) The structure of the other arguments hasn’t changed. xApp API ⚓︎ The xApp API has a small change. You can check the restapi.py example file in the xApp Framework _example _folder. As you can see, we now pass the xapp parameter for access to the xapp class. We also now don’t start the Tornado API in the restapi.py file. We explain how custom xApp API can be added in the Adding an endpoint behind the /api section. As can be seen, the xApp API is created now with the xApp Builder: builder.restapi([ ("/api/", MainApiHandler), ("/api/actions", ActionsHandler), ("/api/request", RequestHandler), ]) Hence the previous xApp API endpoints you have to define in the xApp Buidler. Next, in the restapi.py, you can change the in_queue parameter to the xapp parameter, as seen in the restapi.py example. Then, when sending a message from the xApp API to the main xApp, we used to do: self.in_queue.put("Message from restapi main handler") Which is now: self.xapp.insert_message("Message from restapi main handler")
docs.title: Appendix: Conversion from the xApp Framework to the xApp Library

docs.text: Appendix: Pushing to Dockerhub ⚓︎ One example remote Docker image repository is Dockerhub. Create an account and log in on https://hub.docker.com/ . Click on Create Repository and name it <xapp-name>. Log into the Docker Hub from the command line using: docker login --username=yourdockerhubusername --email=[name@company.com](mailto:name@company.com) Enter your password when prompted. Check the IMAGE ID of your local xApp Docker image: docker images Tag your xApp Docker image by using its IMAGE ID: docker tag <image-id> yourdockerhubusername/<xapp-name>:<xapp-version> Push your xApp Docker image to the repository you created: ~~~ docker push yourdockerhubusername/
docs.title: Appendix: Pushing to Dockerhub

docs.text: Development Workflows ⚓︎ The xApp Dev Environment described in the Quick Guide section is a great way to quickly deploy the full xApp Framework, with the xApp Library in place and the xApp fully integrated into dRAX. In this section, we will explain the different workflows you can use in the development cycle. Development in the container ⚓︎ Once the xApp Dev Environment is deployed, you can access the xApp Dev Environment container as described in the Quick Guide section: kubectl exec -it <pod_name> -- /bin/bash As part of the xApp Dev Environment, we have pre-installed tools such as: vim nano Git You are of course free to install any additional packages. This initial set should be enough to get you started in editing the xApp python files and backing up your code to Git. You can start the xApp by running: python3 xapp_main.py Using ssh to access container ⚓︎ If for any reason you don’t have access to the dRAX host machine or the kubectl command, you can also access the xApp Dev Environment using ssh. First, discover which port is used on the host machine as the ssh port for your xApp Dev environment. You can do this by going to the dRAX Dashboard and navigating to xApps Management -> Overview . Find you xApp Dev Environment, and click the Show button under the Services column. You should see multiple services associated with your xApp, one of which should be the dev-ssh service. You will find the port on which this service is exposed under the NodePort column (it will be in the range of 30 000 - 32 000). You can now ssh into your xApp Dev Environment by using the IP of the dRAX host machine, the dev-ssh service nodePort, and the SSH Password set during the deployment of the xApp Dev Environment: ssh -p <dev-ssh-nodeport> xapp@<drax-host-ip> You now have access to the python files in the xApp Core which are located in _/home/xapp/xapp_core _inside the container. You can edit the python files and start the xApp as normal using: python3 xapp_main.py Using local IDE to edit xApp Dev Environment files ⚓︎ As an xApp developer, it is often easier to develop the xApp in an IDE or user-friendly text editor. You may use a tool called sshfs to mount the files from the xApp Dev Environment container onto your local machine. This way you can edit the files locally in any text editor you want, and the changes will also take effect in the dRAX Dev Environment. Of course, you still need to access the xApp Dev Environment of ssh into it to actually start or stop the xApp! You can install sshfs using the following command: sudo apt install -y sshfs Next create a folder where you will mount the remote files: mkdir /path/to/xapp-dev-file Finally use the sshfs command to mount the files: sshfs -p <dev-ssh-node-port> xapp@<drax-host-ip>:/home/xapp/xapp_core /path/to/xapp-dev-files The xapp_core files will now be available in the "xapp-dev-files" folder you just created. NOTE: You still have to access the xApp Development Environment via kubectl or ssh into it in order to run the actual xApp with the "python3 xapp_main.py" command. Using Visual Studio Code for an integrated development environment ⚓︎ You can use Visual Studio Code to get an integrated development environment. Visual Studio Code has the "remote-ssh" extension which lets you connect to a remote ssh host, access the remote files in the user friendly text editor of VS Code, and have a terminal open to the remote host. Install VS Code ⚓︎ You can download the VS Code from: https://code.visualstudio.com/download Install Remote-SSH in VS Code ⚓︎ You need to install the remote-ssh extension in VS Code, and configure it to connect to your xApp Dev Environment (taking into account the ssh password and port used). In the left hand menu, select the Extensions tab. Search for Remote-SSH and install the extension. Adding the xApp Dev Environment as new SSH host ⚓︎ Next, click F1 on the keyboard to open the Command Pallete (or VSCode -> View -> Command Palette). Now start typing "remote-ssh add new" and select the option that appears: "Remote-SSH: Add New SSH Host…". Follow the instruction to enter the ssh command: ssh -p <dev-ssh-port> xapp@<drax-host-ip> You will be asked to supply a ssh config file. Since we will use the password for ssh, you can just pick the default one. Or if you know what you are doing, you can create or select your ssh config file. Connecting to xApp Dev Environment ⚓︎ You can now find the newly added host, or your xApp Dev Environment, in the “Remote Explorer” tab on the left. You will see the host and can click on it to connect. You will be asked for the ssh password in the process (you might be asked for the ssh password a couple of times which is normal). Adding a SSH key to the xApp Dev Environment ⚓︎ You can of course add your public ssh key to the xApp Dev Environment and then use that in the ssh config file of VS Code Remote-SSH, which makes the connection process easier. Of course you have to keep in mind that once the xApp Dev environment is deleted, all your data in the xApp Dev Environment including the ssh key will be deleted. When deploying a new xApp Dev Environment, you have to set up the ssh key again. Troubleshooting ⚓︎ There is a known issue if you try to connect to the remote xApp Dev Environment using the remote-ssh extension in VS Code. When you try to connect, you can get an error message: “Could not establish connection to “10.8.0.1”: Downloading VS Code Server failed - please install either curl or wget on the remote” To resolve it, you need to kill the VS Code server on the remote using the following command: VSCode -> View -> Command Palette -> input "remote" -> Select Remote-SSH: Kill VS Code Server on Host… You can then select the IP address of your xApp Dev Environment, and will be required to enter the ssh password. Once the process completes, reconnect to the remote ssh again and it should work this time.
docs.title: Development Workflows

docs.text: Introduction ⚓︎ dRAX is Accelleran’s O-RAN aligned Cloud Native RAN platform. dRAX is cloud native by design and encompasses the O-RAN defined CU function, a Service Management and Orchestration (SMO) layer, as well as a near real-time RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC) platform. It features a micro-service oriented architecture with containerized functions orchestrated via Kubernetes and supports both 4G and 5G technologies. The dRAX RIC platform is a Near Real-Time platform. It allows developers to implement xApps that can leverage dRAX near real-time open RAN data and communicate with other xApps to bring new services and functionalities. It offers seamless integration with other orchestration platforms and lowers the technology barrier to implement Enterprise cellular networks by implementing artificial intelligence techniques for the configuration and operation of private cellular networks. This document serves as the developers guide in creating and deploying xApps on the Accelleran dRAX. To make the development and integration of xApps into dRAX as smooth as possible, we have created the dRAX xApp Framework. This framework consists of a number of predefined and pre-developed resources that can communicate with the rest of the entities within the dRAX RIC. This allows the framework to seamlessly integrate with dRAX on deployment. Using abstractions of the lower level details, the xApp Framework exposes easy to use methods which allows the developers to only focus on the functionality of their xApp. The dRAX xApp Framework consists of the following components, which are shown on Figure 2 : The xApp Library - a Python library which interfaces with the dRAX RIC platform The xApp Database - Redis server for storage of configuration data The xApp Core - the core logic of the xApp written by the developer The xApp Helm Chart - a Helm Chart used to deploy the xApp and integrate it with dRAX RIC Figure: dRAX xApps Framework
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: Quick guide ⚓︎ This section introduces you to a development sandbox called the xApp Dev Environment, which can be easily deployed on an existing dRAX installation, in order to gain familiarity with the capabilities of our xApp Framework. We have basically created a Hello-World example inside of the xApp Core using the xApp Library, built a Docker image and prepared a remotely available Helm Chart. Deploy the xApp Dev Environment ⚓︎ The xApp Dev Environment can be easily deployed in a user friendly way via the dRAX Dashboard. Open the dRAX Dashboard, and using the left hand side tabs navigate to: New Deployment -> xApp Deployment . In the newly opened form, from the Method drop-down menu, select Deploy xApp Development Environment . Next, fill in the metadata fields, such as your xApps name, organization team, etc. The Version field indicates which version of the xApp Dev Environment to use. Leave this at “latest”, as this automatically picks the latest stable version of the xApp Dev Environment for your version of dRAX. Finally, the xApp Dev Environment also has the possibility to be accessed via ssh from remote. Therefore, you have to set the ssh password which will be used in the Developer SSH Password field. Note: Enter a password between 7 to 15 characters which contains at least one numeric digit and a special character. Click the Submit button to deploy the xApp Dev Environment. Accessing the xApp Dev Environment Once you deploy the xApp Dev Env, you can check if all its pods are deployed. The xApp pods have a naming convention based on the metadata you provided: <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version> This can be used to filter the pods in the kubectl command: kubectl get pods Once all the pods are in running state, you can access the xApp Dev Environment by using the following command: You can now access the xApp Dev Environment by going into the container in Kubernetes. The xApp pods have a naming convention based on the metadata you provided: <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version> When the xApp is deployed you will have 2 pods in Kubernetes: <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version> <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version>-xapp-redis The xApp Core is located under the <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version> pod, so to access the development environment you can: kubectl exec -it <pod_name> -- /bin/bash Start the xApp in the development environment ⚓︎ Finally you can start your xApp by issuing the following command inside the container: python3 xapp_main.py Edit the xApp ⚓︎ The developer is free to edit the xapp_main.py and create other .py files. You can stop the currently running xapp_main.py, edit the files and restart the xApp again. This allows you to work in a sandbox environment, all fully integrated into dRAX, and focus only on the functionality you bring. How to uninstall the xApp ⚓︎ You can simply delete the xApp Dev Environment by clicking the Uninstall button on the xApp Overview page on the dRAX Dashboard. Navigate to xApp Management -> Overview . NOTE: Please note that any changes will be lost once the sandbox deployment is removed. Therefore it is important to backup your work before deleting the xApp Dev Environment. In the xApp Dev Environment container, we have also pre-installed git, so you are free to use it to backup your code to a remote Git repository. In the following section we will explore how to move from the xApp Dev Environment to a productized xApp.
docs.title: Quick guide

docs.text: This section introduces you to a development sandbox called the xApp Dev Environment, which can be easily deployed on an existing dRAX installation, in order to gain familiarity with the capabilities of our xApp Framework. We have basically created a Hello-World example inside of the xApp Core using the xApp Library, built a Docker image and prepared a remotely available Helm Chart.
docs.title: Quick guide

docs.text: The xApp Dev Environment can be easily deployed in a user friendly way via the dRAX Dashboard. Open the dRAX Dashboard, and using the left hand side tabs navigate to: New Deployment -> xApp Deployment . In the newly opened form, from the Method drop-down menu, select Deploy xApp Development Environment . Next, fill in the metadata fields, such as your xApps name, organization team, etc. The Version field indicates which version of the xApp Dev Environment to use. Leave this at “latest”, as this automatically picks the latest stable version of the xApp Dev Environment for your version of dRAX. Finally, the xApp Dev Environment also has the possibility to be accessed via ssh from remote. Therefore, you have to set the ssh password which will be used in the Developer SSH Password field. Note: Enter a password between 7 to 15 characters which contains at least one numeric digit and a special character. Click the Submit button to deploy the xApp Dev Environment. Accessing the xApp Dev Environment Once you deploy the xApp Dev Env, you can check if all its pods are deployed. The xApp pods have a naming convention based on the metadata you provided: <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version> This can be used to filter the pods in the kubectl command: kubectl get pods Once all the pods are in running state, you can access the xApp Dev Environment by using the following command: You can now access the xApp Dev Environment by going into the container in Kubernetes. The xApp pods have a naming convention based on the metadata you provided: <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version> When the xApp is deployed you will have 2 pods in Kubernetes: <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version> <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version>-xapp-redis The xApp Core is located under the <organization>-<team>-<xapp_name>-<version> pod, so to access the development environment you can: kubectl exec -it <pod_name> -- /bin/bash
docs.title: Deploy the xApp Dev Environment

docs.text: Finally you can start your xApp by issuing the following command inside the container: python3 xapp_main.py
docs.title: Start the xApp in the development environment

docs.text: The developer is free to edit the xapp_main.py and create other .py files. You can stop the currently running xapp_main.py, edit the files and restart the xApp again. This allows you to work in a sandbox environment, all fully integrated into dRAX, and focus only on the functionality you bring.
docs.title: Edit the xApp

docs.text: You can simply delete the xApp Dev Environment by clicking the Uninstall button on the xApp Overview page on the dRAX Dashboard. Navigate to xApp Management -> Overview . NOTE: Please note that any changes will be lost once the sandbox deployment is removed. Therefore it is important to backup your work before deleting the xApp Dev Environment. In the xApp Dev Environment container, we have also pre-installed git, so you are free to use it to backup your code to a remote Git repository. In the following section we will explore how to move from the xApp Dev Environment to a productized xApp.
